context: In the medieval Islamic world, an elementary school was known as a <a1_0><b6_0>maktab<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which dates back to at least the <a0_0><b5_0>10th century<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Like madaris (which referred to higher education), a maktab was often attached to an endowed mosque. In the 11th century, the famous Persian Islamic philosopher and teacher <a2_0><b7_0>Ibn Sīnā<b7_0/><a2_0/> (known as Avicenna in the West), in one of his books, wrote a chapter about the maktab entitled "The Role of the Teacher in the Training and Upbringing of Children," as a guide to teachers working at maktab schools. He wrote that children can learn better if taught in <a3_0>classes<a3_0/> instead of individual tuition from <b8_0>private tutors<b8_0/>, and he gave a number of reasons for why this is the case, citing the value of <b9_0>competition and emulation<b9_0/> among pupils, as well as the usefulness of group discussions and debates. Ibn Sīnā described the curriculum of a maktab school in some detail, describing the curricula for <a4_0>two<a4_0/> stages of education in a maktab school.
